text: Hi, I’m Michael.
This is Lessons from the Screenplay.

A few weeks ago I was approached by Matt from
Nando V Movies—
like Nick Fury assembling a team of avengers—

to be part of a video series by a group of
creators where we all look at

interesting scenes in the Marvel Cinematic
Universe.

A link to the playlist of all these videos
is in the description below,
and will be at the end of the video as well.

As I thought about my favorite scenes in the
MCU,

my mind quickly went to the car ride scene
in Spider-Man: Homecoming.

At first glance, this scene could be straight
out of any high school comedy,

especially since the film was intentionally
modeled

after the John Hughes high school comedies
of the 80’s.
Peter, a nervous sophomore,

is on the way to his first school dance with
his date and her father.
"You alright, Pete?"
"Yeah."

But being in a superhero film, and following
a huge revelation in the story,
it is also a scene of real tension—

three characters trapped in car, trying to
hide some really big secrets.

So today I want to explore why the twist that
sets the stage for the scene
is so effective...

To examine how the characters’ secrets are
teased out in a way
that keeps the scene dynamic...

And to look at the importance of crafting
clever obstacles
to put in the way of your characters.

Let’s take a look at the car ride scene
in Spider-Man: Homecoming.

Throughout the first hour and twenty-seven
minutes of the film,

Peter’s relationship with Adrian—A.K.A.
the Vulture—is very clear.
Peter wants to catch the Vulture...

“The guy with the wings is obviously the
source of the weapons.
I gotta take him down.”
...Adrian wants to kill Spider-Man.
“I’m gonna kill him.”
Superhero, villain.
Simple.

But when Peter arrives to take Liz to the
homecoming dance,

the simple hero-villain relationship quickly
becomes complicated.
“You must be Peter.
I’m Liz’s dad.”
This twist is a legitimate surprise,

but it’s powerful because the audience immediately
understands the implications.

The girl Peter has had a crush on the whole
film is the daughter of his enemy.
We know that he is now in a difficult situation,

and we immediately wonder what Peter is going
to do.
“What are you going to do, Pete?”
“What?”
There are three characters in this scene,

and their differing levels of knowledge is
what creates the drama.
First, there is Peter, our protagonist.
Peter knows what the audience knows—
that he is Spider-Man and that Adrian is the Vulture.

Adrian, the antagonist, knows that he is the Vulture,
of course,

but doesn’t know that he’s currently in
the car with his mortal enemy.
And finally, Liz knows none of this.
She’s just in the car with her normal dad

on the way to the homecoming dance with her
normal date.
By the end of the scene,

Liz will be unaware of what has unfolded and
her role in it,
but Adrian will have learned everything.

However his path of discovering Peter’s
secret isn’t a straight line.
Instead the tension ebbs and flows,

as there are moments when it seems Peter may
escape the situation undetected.
Let’s walk through the beats of the scene.
“What are you going to do, Pete?”
It begins innocently enough,

Adrian is simply asking Peter what he’s
going to do after high school.

“You guys that go to that school, you pretty
much have your life planned out right?”

But Liz’s interjection includes some intriguing
information:

“Peter has an internship with Tony Stark,
so I think he doesn’t have to worry.”
“Really?
Stark?
What do you do?”

Peter tries to deflect by saying he doesn’t
have the internship anymore,
but this just creates more problems.
“Yeah. It got...boring.”
“It was boring?
You got to hang out with Spider-Man.”
“Really?
Spider-Man?
Wow. What’s he like?”

Both Peter and the audience know the real
reason Adrian is interested.
Peter tries to throw Adrian off the scent,
emphasizing that Spider-Man is an adult
and definitely not a sophomore in high school.
“Yeah he’s nice.
Nice man.
Solid dude.”
The subject is dropped...

but now Adrian is onto an even more dangerous
train of thought.
“I’ve seen you around right?
I mean, somewhere we’ve...
Because even the voice…”

It’s clear that Adrian is starting to suspect
something.

But here, Liz offers information that quells
his suspicions.
“He does academic decathlon with me.”
“Ah.”

- “And he was at my party.” 
- “Ah.”
Liz has given Peter an alibi.

If he was at Liz’s party, he couldn’t
have been Spider-Man doing battle with Vulture.
“It was a great party.
Really great.
Beautiful house.
Lot of windows.”

But in her innocence, Liz giveth and Liz taketh
away.
“You were there for like two seconds.”
“I was there for longer than two seconds.”
“You disappeared.”
“No, I did not disappear.”

“Yes you did, you disappeared like you always
do.
Like you did in D.C. too.”

In any other situation Adrian would most likely
confront Peter immediately,

but the reason he doesn’t points to the
final element
of what makes this scene so fun.
“Look, so cute!”
Liz is in the car.

Liz is at once the element that provides Adrian
with the information to deduce Peter’s secret,

and the obstacle that prevents both him and
Peter from directly pursuing their goals.

Peter’s very last chance at an alibi in
the scene

would be to lie and say that he was in the
elevator in D.C.
and was saved by Spider-Man,
but Liz knows the truth, so he can’t.
“I actually didn’t go up.
I saw it all from the ground.”
“Good ole Spider-Man.”

We also know that Peter and Adrian care about
Liz.

They’re not only hiding their secrets from
each other, but from her.

So even once Adrian has figured out that Peter
is Spider-Man,

he can’t do anything about it in front of
Liz.

Which is why in the next scene he sends Liz
into the dance, and talks to Peter alone.
“You head in there, gumdrop.
I’m going to give Peter ‘the dad talk.’”

In just a few pages, this scene has flipped
the story on its head.

The antagonist has discovered our hero’s
secret identity,
and now has the upper hand.

And the scene is so fun to watch because all
of this was revealed via subtext.

The presence of a clever obstacle forces the
characters to subtly maneuver around it

instead of throwing on their outfits and starting
to punch each other.

On the surface it’s simply a father driving
his daughter and her date
to the homecoming dance,

but underneath it’s a hero and villain doing
battle
while navigating a unique web of obstacles.

“Of all the reasons I didn’t want my daughter
to date.”

I love this scene because it takes the epic
stakes of most Marvel films

and squeezes them down to fit inside a single
car.

It’s a great example of the tension that
can be created

when there are clever obstacles put in the
way of the characters’ clearly-defined goals.
And in my opinion,

it shows what the Marvel Cinematic Universe
can be at its best—

as this combination of high-school comedy
and superhero battle is the kind of scene
that could only happen in Spider-Man: Homecoming.

I love being on set,

and we had a ton of fun shooting our previous
video on Adaptation.
The whole team did a great job,

and I learned a ton from spending four days
in front of the camera for a change.

One of the most time-intensive aspects of
the short was doing a visual effect
that hopefully no one thought twice about.

All the computer screens had to be created
digitally

because we shot all them all with a blue
screen on set.

This technique gives you a ton of flexibility
in post,

and is one of the many things that After Effects
is great at.
